awd_titl_txt: Chain Trajectory of Semicrystalline Polymers in Bulk and Single Crystals by Solid-state NMR
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project aims to shed light on a centrally important but controversial issue in polymer crystallization, namely the trajectory of the molecular chains throughout the crystal and to answer the question of how do polymer chains deposit at the growth front in polymer crystals.  The PI proposes a new experimental scheme to elucidate the chain trajectory of polymers in bulk and single crystals based on 13C selective isotope labeling and advanced solid-state NMR. Here, combined use of 1) specific isotope labeling, 2) 13C-13C spatial correlation, and high resolution NMR will allow to access chain trajectory (adjacent re-entry fractions and directions) of polymer chains in the crystalline regions. Using this new strategy, the PI will investigate how i) chemical structures such as functions, chemical defect, and molecular weights, ii) kinetics, and iii) entanglements influence chain trajectory in crystalline regions.  This information is particularly important for understanding polymer crystallization on a molecular level.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymers are important synthetic materials whose properties depend critically on the structure of their constituent crystals.  While their structures have been studied for decades, details of the location and trajectory of individual polymer molecules (which resemble very long chains) are still uncertain.  Techniques used so far have led to disagreements and controversial interpretations in the literature.  The PI proposes a combination of new advanced magnetic resonance methodologies and precise chemical labeling of the polymer molecules to help shed an answer to these questions.  The students will benefit from interdisciplinary education in polymer chemistry and physics, as well as gaining expertise in advanced characterization techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polymer crystallization induces drastic structural change from random coils in the melt and solution states to folded chains in the thin lamellar crystals with a typical thickness of ca. 5-20 nm in the melt- and solution-grown crystals, respectively. The crystallization of polymers driven by kinetics yields unique features in terms of crystal habits, lamellar thickness, and crystallinity among other characteristics. Trajectory of individual polymer chains records the structural changes during the crystallization process. Thereby, theoretical and experimental studies have focused on understanding the chain-folding mechanism and structure under different conditions over the last half century. However, elucidation of the detailed chain-folding structure remains challenging due to experimental limitations. In this project,  we developed a novel experimental strategy using 13C-13C double quantum (DQ) NMR and numerical spin-dynamics simulation to determine for the first time the detailed chain-folding structure of 13C labeled polymers in solution- and melt-grown crystals across a wider range of crystallization temperatures. It was demonstrated that i) flexible polymer chains adopts adjacent re-entry rich structures in bot melt- and solution-grown crystals, ii) a mean value of adjacent re-entry sequence in solution-grown crystals is longer than that in melt-grown crystals, iii) kinetics does not play significant role for determining adjacent re-entry sequence length in both melt- and solution-grown crystals, and folded chains form three dimensional conformation in solution-grown single crystals. These newly obtained structures allows us to understand crystallization mechanisms at molecular levels as well as to verify validity of existing theories.


Last Modified: 11/17/2015
Modified by: Toshikazu Miyoshi

Thereby, theoretical and experimental studies have focused on understanding the chain-folding mechanism and structure under different conditions over the last half century. However, elucidation of the detailed chain-folding structure remains challenging due to experimental limitations.
